Graphical abstract Thermocatalytic decomposition of methane (TCD) is a promising approach for producing CO2-free hydrogen and solid carbon co-product. In this study, a series of Al2O3- and MgAl2O4-based Ni catalysts, prepared with varying synthesis and pretreatment methods, were evaluated for methane TCD performance at 650 °C and characterized before and after reaction to elucidate activity-structure relationships. We found that methane TCD turnover increases with Ni particle size. Further, large Ni particle sizes (i.e., >20 nm) are selective toward the formation of carbon nanotubes (CNTs), while small Ni particle sizes (i.e., <10 nm) are selective toward the formation of graphitic carbon layers. The formation of graphitic carbon layers block access to Ni active sites, thus rendering the catalyst inactive more quickly than when CNTs are produced. Additionally, the catalyst deactivation observed with time-on-stream is due to the fragmentation of Ni particles into smaller Ni particles followed by their encapsulation with graphitic carbon layers. Keywords Thermocatalytic decomposition Ni catalysts Carbon nanotubes Structure sensitivity Ni particle size 1 Introduction Hydrogen (H2) has received significant attention as a clean energy carrier for many energy applications that currently rely on fossil hydrocarbons [1]. H2 can be generated from hydrocarbons or water by thermochemical, electrochemical, and photochemical means [2]. Electrolysis of water coupled with renewable energy is considered a promising near-term, low-emission technology. However, commercial deployment has been limited due to high electricity input requirements that increase production cost [2]. Instead, approximately 95 % of the global supply of H2 is produced from fossil fuels by stream reforming of natural gas (SMR), oxidation of methane, and gasification of coal [1]. SMR is the most prevalent technology employed to generate H2 and carbon monoxide (CO) at industrial scale (Eq. 1) [2]. In the subsequent water-gas-shift (WGS) reaction, CO and steam are reacted to produce carbon dioxide (CO2) and additional H2 (Eq. 2). (1) CH4 (g) + H2O (g) ↔ CO (g) + 3H2 (g); ΔHo =206 kJ/mol SMR (2) CO (g) + H2O (g) ↔ CO2 (g) + H2 (g);ΔHo = - 41 kJ/mol WGS Combining Eqs. (1) and (2) yields the idealized net reaction for SMR: (3) CH4 (g) + 2H2O (g) ↔ CO2 (g) + 4H2 (g); ΔHo =165 kJ/mol Net Reaction Being a strongly endothermic process, a significant amount of energy is required to provide the heat of reaction. Burning fossil fuels to provide this energy results in the release of additional CO2 [3]. If CO2 capture is considered as part of a clean technology option, significant additional cost would be incurred. Alternatively, thermocatalytic decomposition (TCD) of methane offers another means to generate CO2-free H2 (Eq. 4) [3,4]. Here, the carbon derived from methane forms a solid co-product instead of gaseous CO2. Further, TCD requires slightly less energy per mole of H2 produced, as it is slightly less endothermic (37.5 kJ/mol H2) compared to the net reaction for SMR (41.3 kJ/mol H2) [5]. However, a primary disadvantage of TCD relative to SMR is that twice as many moles of CH4 reactant are required to produce the same number moles of H2 [3]. Furthermore, rapid catalyst deactivation and separation of catalyst from produced solid carbon co-product remain additional challenges [6]. Nonetheless, TCD has received increased attention as a means for producing CO2-free H2 using, in many regions, widely abundant natural gas as feedstock [3]. (4) CH4 (g) → C (s) + 2H2 (g); ΔHo =75 kJ/molTCD Catalysts usually play a crucial role in reducing the activation energy required by the TCD reaction, thus accelerating the reaction rate and/or lowering the reaction temperature [7]. The most commonly used catalysts in TCD are transition metals including Ni, Co, and Fe on supports including Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, MgO, CeO2, carbon, and zeolites [5,8–15]. Among these catalysts, supported Ni catalysts have been extensively investigated because of their favorable activity at pyrolysis operating conditions. The endothermic nature of the TCD reaction requires relatively high operating temperatures (e.g., >500 °C) to achieve relevant industrial conversions (e.g., >20 %). Under these processing conditions and because carbon formed during the reaction blocks metal active sites, catalysts typically exhibit rapid deactivation [16–19]. Therefore, a significant amount research has focused on enhancing catalyst stability by adding other metals to the Ni (e.g., Co, Fe, Cu) [12,13,18,20–29] and/or modifying the support [19,30–34]. Bimetallic and trimetallic catalysts have been reported to offer prolonged stability, higher methane conversion, better thermal resistance, and improved coke resistance relative to their monometallic counterparts [35]. This benefit is attributed to structural and electronic rearrangements that occur during alloy formation [36]. For example, Kutteri et al. [36] investigated Ni-Co/SiO2 catalysts for methane TCD at 650 °C and found that a bimetallic system offered relatively stable TCD activity for 60 min where, by comparison, a corresponding Ni/SiO2 catalyst became nearly completely deactivated within 20 min. Adding Co (or other metals) to Ni reportedly enhances the ability to diffuse carbon, thus avoiding the formation of encapsulating carbon [35,36]. Modifying the support with metal oxide additives (e.g., ZnO, CeO2, MgO) [31–33] or by altering its physical structure (e.g., use of sol-gel synthesis or introducing mesoporosity) [19,30,34] also has been reported to improve catalyst activity and stability. For example, Latorre et al. [33] reported the addition of MgO to Ni-Al forms a spinel that strengthens the Ni-Al metal-support interaction and increases dispersion of Ni2+ in the MgO crystalline framework, thus preventing Ni particle agglomeration. Additionally, Hu and co-workers [19] studied a Ni-Co bimetallic system when supported by an Al2O3 support prepared by the sol-gel technique. In both cases, enhanced stability was attributed to improved metal dispersion due to stronger metal-support interaction, which led to higher utilization of metal species (i.e., higher fractional exposure) that enhanced catalytic activity and stability. On the other hand, metal particles that are too small are known to deactivate relatively quickly due to the formation of graphitic carbon layers that encapsulate the metal active sites [35]. Favorable TCD stability often is affected by the morphology of the carbon co-products (i.e., CNTs or carbon nanofilms vs. encapsulating carbon species) and degree of graphitization [35,37]. Literature studies have reported ways in which catalyst properties (e.g., surface area, composition) can affect the resulting carbon co-product, and Ni particle size has been reported to be an important parameter [27,38–41]. However, carefully controlled studies evaluating the effect of systematic changes in catalyst properties on catalytic performance is lacking. As a result, a direct correlation between catalyst properties such as Ni particle size, for example when using the same catalyst support, and its effect on TCD activity, stability, and carbon selectivity have not been reported, to the best of our knowledge. In this study, we investigated a series of Al2O3-and MgAl2O4-based Ni catalysts with varying pretreatment methods for methane TCD performance at 650 °C. This resulted in the study of catalysts with varied supports and, therefore, with different catalytic properties (e.g., metal-support interaction, surface area). Also, catalysts with Ni particle sizes varied by adjusting reduction temperature were evaluated when using the same support. Catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2 TPR), H2 chemisorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO), and Raman spectroscopy to elucidate a relationship between TCD performance and catalytic properties. Our results indicate that the Ni particle size is the main parameter that controls TCD performance and carbon co-product selectivity, for the catalysts evaluated in this study. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and catalyst synthesis A series of Al2O3-based Ni catalysts were prepared as follows: Ni/Al2O3 aerogel, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/MgAl2O4, and Ni-Al2O3 spinel (comprising both NiAl2O4 and Al2O3) with a constant nominal Ni loading of 10 wt.%. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Sigma Aldrich) was used as a precursor. After synthesis, all the catalysts were pelletized and sieved to 30–60 mesh. Ni/Al2O3 aerogel was prepared by a sol-gel method reported by Gao and co-workers [19]. In a typical synthesis, 8.52 g AlCl3·6H2O (Acros Organics) and 1 g Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 5.5 ml distilled water and 15.5 ml ethanol while stirring. The solution then was heated to 80 °C and held at that temperature for 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solution was mixed with 16 ml propylene oxide (Acros Organic) in an ice bath and held still for 30 min to form a gel. The gel was aged further with ethanol at 50 °C for 24 h and dried under vacuum at 80 °C. The final products were calcined at 600 °C for 8 h. Ni/γ-Al2O3 was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) of an aqueous solution of the Ni precursor onto γ-Al2O3 (STREM, acidic). The slurry then was dried at 110 °C overnight, and the dry solids were calcined at 500 °C for 10 h at a heating ramp of 5 °C min−1. MgAl2O4 was prepared from a commercial Sasol Puralox 30/150 and was calcined at 800 °C for 2 h at a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1 prior to use. Ni was deposited by IWI of an aqueous solution of the Ni precursor. The slurry then was dried at 110 °C overnight, and the dry solids were calcined at 500 °C for 10 h at a heating ramp of 5 °C min−1. Ni-Al2O3 spinel was synthesized using γ-Al2O3 as support and depositing Ni by IWI to obtain a Ni:Al ratio of 1:10 (with 10 wt.% Ni). After impregnation, the slurry was dried at 110 °C overnight and calcined at 900 °C for 6 h at a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1 (to form NiAl2O4 phase). 2.2 Catalyst characterization Measurement of N2 physisorption was performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 at 77 K to determine Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda pore size and volume. Samples were degassed at 150 °C under vacuum for 12 h. Metal loadings were measured by an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry. A Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 instrument was used to conduct H2 temperature-programmed-reduction (H2-TPR) and H2-chemisorption over fresh catalysts, and TPO over spent catalysts. For H2-TPR, samples were heated at 150 °C for 120 min under He flow. After cooling to ambient temperature, samples were heated to 1020 °C at a ramp rate of 3 °C min−1 and held for 60 min under 5% H2/Ar while recording TCD signals. H2-chemisorption was used to determine H2 uptakes. Samples were reduced at either 650 °C or 800 °C for 3 h at a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1 under 5% H2/Ar. Then, the sample s was purged with Ar for 60 min. H2-chemisorption measurements were performed at 100 °C under 5% H2/Ar. For TPO, samples were loaded and pretreated at 120 °C for 120 min under He. Then samples were heated to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1 under 5% O2/He. XRD analysis was performed on a Philips X’Pert Powder XRD with a Cu Kα source at 50 kV and 40 mA. Fresh catalysts were first ex situ reduced for 3 h at a heating ramp of 5 °C min−1 under 50 sccm 5% H2/N2. After the sample cooled to room temperature, the gas was switched to 1% O2/N2 overnight after returning to passivate the sample before XRD (and TEM) analysis. The spent catalysts were loaded as-retrieved from the reactor system. Catalysts were scanned from 10°–80° at a scan speed of 2° 2θ/min with a step size of 0.06° 2θ/step. Whole-pattern (Rietveld) fitting of XRD patterns with Topas V6 (Bruker AXS) was used to determine Ni(0) average crystallite size (i.e., average particle size), relative concentration and/or the crystallite dimensions of Ni0 using procedures similar to those described in previous work [42]. An inverse spinel structure with charge-balanced substitution of Al3+ and site vacancies for Ni2+ was used to model the spinel fraction when determining Ni(°) concentrations; when determining crystallite size alone, a structureless cubic phase with freely refined peak intensities (i.e., a Pawley phase) was used along with the FCC Ni structure. For all phases, the unit cell parameters and a parameter describing peak broadening from crystallite size were refined. Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw InVia Raman microscope with a 532 nm excitation wavelength at 5 mW laser power. Each spectrum was generated by three scans to analyze properties of solid carbons produced from the methane decomposition reaction. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was used to determine the morphology of solid carbon co-products and Ni particle size. The analysis was performed on a FEI Titan 80–300 microscope operated at 300 kV, equipped with a CEOS GmbH double-hexapole aberration corrector for the probe-forming lens, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy detector. Ni particle size distribution also was calculated from HRTEM images with at least of 500 particles located in different areas. 2.3 Reactor apparatus and catalytic tests Methane TCD reactions were carried out in a vertical stainless steel, continuous-flow, fixed-bed reactor (¼-in. outer diameter × 24-in. length) at atmospheric pressure. The reaction conditions were chosen so that the catalysts would show deactivation within 1 h of reaction to elucidate correlations between catalytic performance and surface properties. The reaction temperature was 650 °C and measured by a K-type thermocouple fixed at the catalyst bed. Catalysts weighing 0.3 g were loaded and held in place with quartz wool. N2 gas was used as a carrier gas and an internal standard for product analysis using on-line gas chromatography (GC). Prior to each test, the catalysts were reduced at different temperatures (e.g., 650 °C or 800 °C) for 3 h under 70 sccm 10 vol.% H2/N2 at a ramp rate of 3 °C min−1. Subsequently, the reactor temperature was set to the reaction temperature (i.e., 650 °C) under 70 sccm of N2 and maintained until H2 was completely purged from the system (monitored by on-line GC). Then, the feed was switched to 70 sccm of 30 vol.% CH4/N2 to maintain a constant gas hour space velocity of 14,000 h−1 for all the experiments. The outlet gas flow rate was measured by a digital flow meter (DryCal). N2, CH4, H2, CO, and CO2 composition of the outlet gas was analyzed by a four-channel Agilent Micro GC equipped with Molecular Sieve 5A, PLOT U, alumina, and OV-1 columns and a TCD detector for each column. Under our reaction conditions, H2 was the only gaseous product detected above background. When the test concluded, the reactor system was cooled to room temperature under 70 sccm of N2, and the spent catalysts (containing solid carbon co-product) were retrieved from the reactor for analysis. CH4 conversion was calculated based on the amount of H2 produced as shown in Eqs. 5–7. Ni/Al2O3 aerogel, Ni/γ-Al2O3, and Ni-Al2O3 spinel exhibited different surface areas due to the synthesis methods. Among them, Ni/Al2O3 aerogel showed the highest surface area of 328 m2 g−1. However, Ni-Al2O3 spinel, which was synthesized at 900 °C to form spinel structure, had a surface area of only 81 m2 g−1. Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4 showed similar surface areas of 123 and 102 m2 g−1, respectively. N2 physisorption was performed over fresh catalysts reduced at 650 and 800 °C, respectively. To quantify surface area changes during the reduction step. At 650 °C, the surface area of Ni/Al2O3 aerogel decrease by 15 % while Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni-Al2O3 spinel and Ni/MgAl2O4 did not experience significant changes in surface area (<10 %). At 800 °C, the surface area of Ni/Al2O3 aerogel decreased by 32 %. The Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni-Al2O3 spinel and Ni/MgAl2O4 showed a lower decrease (<22 %) in surface area. The pore volume of the Ni/Al2O3 aerogel was similar for the as-synthesized and reduced-at-650 °C samples. However, the pore volume decreased by 14 % due to the increase in reduction temperature (from 650 °C to 800 °C) as shown in Table S1. Interestingly, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni-Al2O3 spinel, and Ni/MgAl2O4 had no appreciable changes in pore volumes when comparing the as-synthesized samples with the samples reduced at 650 °C and 800 °C. H2-TPR profiles of the fresh pristine samples are shown in Fig. 1 . Ni/γ-Al2O3 had a sharp peak around 500 °C, while Ni/Al2O3 aerogel and Ni/MgAl2O4 exhibited broader peaks at higher temperatures, indicating that Ni is harder to reduce. This is consistent with previous reports that correlate the increase in H2-TPR profiles to a better dispersion of metal particles using the aerogel structure [19] and to a stronger metal-support interaction for the MgAl2O4 as the support [43], respectively. Ni-Al2O3 spinel showed the highest reduction peak at 750 °C likely because Ni was preferentially in the NiAlxOy phase (as opposed to a NiO phase for the other catalysts) and required higher temperatures to reduce Ni to the Ni(°) phase. XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts are compared in Fig. 2 and shows that the preferred state of Ni is metallic (i.e., Ni(0)) regardless of the reduction temperature, with the exception of Ni/Al2O3 spinel reduced at 650 °C. For example, when reduced at 650 °C, Ni/Al2O3 aerogel and Ni/γ-Al2O3 exhibited Ni(0) features with primary peaks around 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4°. No NiO features were observed. The presence of the γ-Al2O3 support was confirmed by its characteristic peaks around 37.8°, 45.9°, and 66.7°. For Ni/MgAl2O4, both Ni(0) and MgAl2O4 features were found. For these three catalysts, no significant changes in XRD spectra were observed between reduction at 650 °C and 800 °C. However, Ni-Al2O3 spinel reduced at 650 °C had Ni(0) features at ≈44.5° that overlapped with NiAl2O4/Al2O3. Particularly, NiAl2O4 and Al2O3 phases exhibit close characteristic peaks with lattice spacings and intensities that led us to believe a NiAlxOy phase (not exactly as NiAl2O4 and more toward Al2O3) existed in the sample. Ni(0) was calculated to only occupy a 2.5 wt.% in the sample (Table 1). It suggests that Ni predominantly formed NiAlxOy phase when reduced at 650 °C, which agrees with the H2-TPR peak at 750 °C. When reduced at 800 °C (Fig. 2b), we observed Ni(0) features at ≈44.5° and 51.8°, which increased in relative intensity while the NiAl2O4/Al2O3 peak decreases at ≈45 and 62°. Ni(0) was found to increase to 10 wt.%. These results suggest that the higher reduction temperature (partially) removed the Ni from the NixAlyOz structure to form Ni(0) particles, which agrees with the increase in H2 uptake from reductions at 650–800 °C (5.1 vs. 12.5 μmol g−1, Table 1). Bulk Ni(0) average crystallite sizes (i.e., particle size) also were estimated from XRD data in Table 1 as function of reduction temperature. When the reduction temperature increased from 650–800 °C, Ni/Al2O3 aerogel showed a ≈7% increase in Ni(0) particle size (from 19.4–20.7 nm). Interestingly, the H2 uptake increased by 158 % (4.3 and 11.1 μmol g−1) suggesting that more Ni particles were formed at the catalyst surface as opposed to being imbedded in the aerogel structure. Ni/γ-Al2O3 exhibited a 53 % increase in average Ni(0) particle size when the reduction temperature increase from 650 °C to 800 °C (from 10.4–15.9 nm), which is consistent with TEM imaging (Figure A.1), suggesting that the Ni sintered at higher reduction temperatures, and also consistent with the decrease in H2 uptake (from 8.1–6.8 μmol g−1). Ni-Al2O3 spinel showed a 49 % increase in Ni particle size (from 7.0–10.4 nm) with the increase in reduction temperature; the H2 uptake increased by 145 % (from 5.1–12.5 μmol g−1). This is consistent with our hypothesis that the 800 °C reduction temperature removed Ni from the bulk NiAlxOy to form Ni(0). In addition, H2 uptake for each catalyst (in Table 1) displayed an increase when the reduction temperature increased except that there was a slight decrease for Ni/γ-Al2O3 (8.1 vs 6.8 μmol g−1). An increase ≈17 % in particle size was found for Ni/MgAl2O4 (8.7 vs. 10.2 nm) and the H2 increased by 33 % (from 19.8–26.4 μmol g−1), suggesting that imbedded Ni particles migrated from the bulk to the surface. TEM images and corresponding Ni(0) particle size distributions performed over fresh catalysts under different reduction temperatures are reported in Figure A.1. These results agree with those obtained by XRD. 3.2 Catalytic activity for methane TCD at 650 °C When reduction and reaction temperatures were both at 650 °C, the four catalysts exhibited different initial activities and deactivation profiles (see Fig. 3 a). For example, Ni-Al2O3 spinel had the lowest H2 uptake (5.1 μmol g−1, Table 1) and showed negligible initial activity. According to XRD profiles in Fig. 2a, we hypothesize that Ni-Al2O3 spinel had negligible activity because Ni was predominantly in the NiAlxOy phase (as opposed to Ni(0)). This hypothesis was confirmed with the Ni/Al2O3 aerogel as Ni was predominantly in the Ni(0) phase and it had higher activity than Ni-Al2O3 spinel (reduced at 650 °C) even with similar H2-uptake. These results suggest that the TCD activity is directly correlated to the presence of Ni(0) as opposed to NiAlxOy phase [38]. Similarly, Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4 (reduced at 650 °C) had higher activity than Ni-Al2O3 spinel because Ni was predominantly in the Ni(0) state in the former two catalysts. Ni/y-Al2O3 had the second lowest H2 update (8.1 μmol g−1) and showed higher initial TCD activity (30 % conversion) but deactivated within the first 20 min of reaction. Ni/MgAl2O4 had more than two times higher H2 update than Ni/y-Al2O3, but the initial conversion did not increase proportionally (30 % and 40 % conversion, respectively) and still deactivated within the first 20 min. Notably, Ni/Al2O3 aerogel had the largest average Ni(0) particle size, ≈20 nm, compared to the other catalysts that were ≈10 nm, in Table 1. Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni-Al2O3 spinel, and Ni/MgAl2O4 with similar Ni particle sizes had different surface properties (i.e., Ni phase, H2 uptake) and showed different TCD activities and stabilities. In parallel, Ni/Al2O3 aerogel and Ni/γ-Al2O3 with similar surface properties had different Ni particle sizes (19.4 and 10.4 nm, respectively) and also had different TCD activities and stabilities. These results suggest that TCD activity and stability could be governed by two different parameters, that is 1) surface properties (Ni phase, H2 uptake) and 2) Ni particle size. The role of surface properties and metal particle size was evaluated further by increasing the reduction temperature to 800 °C. Interestingly, the changes in H2 uptakes did not directly correlate to changes in TCD activity nor stability (see Fig. 3b). For example, while we expected Ni/Al2O3 aerogel to become more active and stable after the increase in H2 uptakes (by 158 %), the TCD activity was negligible. Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4 had the smallest change increase in H2 uptake (<33 %) and showed similar performance regardless of the reduction temperature; however, the deactivation rate appeared to be slightly altered. Ni-Al2O3 spinel became active upon reduction at 800 °C but also deactivated within the first 20 min. As hypothesized, the formation of Ni(0) phase was enhanced at 800 °C as opposed to the NixAlyOz phase at 650 °C, suggesting that the increase in TCD activity is directly correlated to the Ni(0) phase. Ni/MgAl2O4 reduced at 800 °C displayed an increase in H2 uptake and a change in particle size (Table 1), which correlated with the enhancement in TCD activity and stability compared to Ni/MgAl2O4 reduced at 650 °C. Consistent with previous reports, Ni(0) appears to be the active phase for TCD. Therefore, to better compare the intrinsic TCD activity (i.e., TOF) among the different catalysts and elucidate possible activity-particle size relationship, the initial TCD activity was normalized by the initial Ni(0) active surface area (estimated by H2 chemisorption) and correlated to initial Ni(0) particle size, Fig. 4 . Ermakova et al. [39] demonstrated that Ni particles can undergo particle size change (i.e., evolution) during methane TCD. Therefore, we used the XRD data for the fresh reduced catalysts to estimate the initial Ni(0) particle size and correlated it to the initial TCD TOF. We note that there generally is good agreement between XRD and TEM Ni(0) particle size determinations (see Table S2), thus confirming the trend. Fig. 4 shows that the TCD TOF increases with Ni(0) particle size independent of catalyst support composition and differences on TPR profiles (Fig. 1). For example, Ni/Al2O3 aerogel and Ni/MgAl2O4 had comparable TPR profiles but the TCD TOF was different because the of the resulting Ni(0) particle size (20 and 9 nm at 650 °C reduction, respectively). On the other hand, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/MgAl2O4, and Ni-Al2O3 spinel had different TPR profiles but showed similar TCD because they had comparable Ni(0) particle size (8.7–10.4 nm). Thus, this work demonstrates that (1) particle size is the main factor affecting the TCD activity and (2) TCD is a structure sensitive reaction on Ni. We note that Ni-Al2O3 spinel reduced at 650 °C was not included because both Ni(0) and NiAlxOy phases existed and contributed to the overall H2 uptakes. Further, we include the Ni(0) particle size for both the fresh reduced and spent Ni/Al2O3 aerogel catalyst reduced at 800 °C. This is because we hypothesize that a drastic reduction in Ni(0) particle size may have occurred very early in the reaction as evidenced by the low initial TCD activity obtained (see Fig. 3b). This catalyst had the largest percentage decrease in Ni(0) particle size after reaction, thus indicating the potential for a high degree of Ni fragmentation. We also report the specific carbon deposition rate (i.e., mass of carbon deposited per unit of time normalized by the total mass of Ni in the catalysts) to better compare to the literature work performed under identical, kinetically-relevant reaction conditions (i.e., atmospheric pressure, 650 °C, 30 vol.% CH4). As shown in Table A.3, the initial specific carbon deposition rates are between 100 and 210 mgC/(gNi∙min) for the catalyst with the largest particle size which, are up to 10 times higher that relevant literature work. For example, Gao et al. reported TCD activity of NiCo/Al2O3 aerogel and Al2O3-TiO2 aerogel of 22 mgC/(gNi∙min). [30,44] Shen et al. reported that Ni/CNT had unappreciable TCD activity, but NiCuPt/CNT catalysts had a specific rate between 40–65 mgC/(gNi∙min) at 650 °C. [45] Because the catalysts were not further characterized, we cannot explain the differences in catalytic rates across the different literature studies and our work; instead, we can only speculate that they are due to a combination of (1) differences in Ni particle size, (2) operating with high metal loadings under different kinetically-relevant reaction conditions (e.g., CH4 vol.%, temperature, total pressure), and (3) not running the catalyst for long enough to observe deactivation. Therefore, our results highlight the importance of properly characterizing the active site and correlating the TCD activity with relevant catalytic parameters, such as, metal particle size. 3.3 Properties of carbon co-products 3.3.1 Crystallinity of carbon co-products TPO was performed over spent catalysts to qualitatively measure the crystallinity of the produced carbon. Fig. 5 shows that all spent catalyst displayed peaks above 350 °C, suggesting that all the carbon was graphitic (amorphous carbon usually shows features at 200–350 °C) [18]. However, the variously shaped TPO peaks indicate that different crystalline carbon morphologies were obtained on the samples. For example, Ni/Al2O3 aerogel reduced at 650 °C was the most TCD active and exhibited a sharp peak around 550 °C (along with a shoulder peak around 575 °C); however, Ni/Al2O3 aerogel reduced at 800 °C was not active for the reaction and showed negligible TPO features. Ni/γ-Al2O3 reduced at both 650 and 800 °C had a similar activity profile (Fig. 3) and similar, broad TPO peak at ≈450 °C, suggesting that that reduction condition did not significantly affect solid carbon crystallinity. Ni-Al2O3 spinel reduced at 800 °C was active for methane TCD (even though it quickly deactivated) and showed broad TPR features at ≈450 °C, similar to Ni/γ-Al2O3; however, Ni-Al2O3 spinel reduced at 650 °C was not active and did not show noticeable TPO features. Ni/MgAl2O4 was more active when reduced at 800 °C than at 650 °C and had similar TPO profiles, but when reduced at 800 °C it had stronger TPO feature. As expected, the TPO profiles correlated with the catalytic activity for all the samples; however, we hypothesize that the shifts in TPO features are associated with changes in carbon co-product morphology, even if all the produced carbon is mostly graphitic at 650 °C. Raman spectroscopy was conducted to quantify the crystallinity of carbon co-products via the intensity ratio between the D band at 1343 cm−1 (corresponding to amorphous or disordered carbon) and the G band at 1580 cm−1 (corresponding to crystalline carbon) [18,34]. As shown in Fig. 6 , ID/IG ratios ranged from 1.13 to 1.22, confirming that the generated carbon was mostly graphitic. Ni/MgAl2O4 reduced at 800 °C and Ni/Al2O3 aerogel reduced at 650 °C had similar ID/IG ratios (1.13 and 1.14, respectively) and similar major TPO feature at 550 °C, suggesting that both catalysts made similar carbon forms. Ni/MgAl2O4 and Ni/γ-Al2O3 reduced at 650 °C, and Ni/γ-Al2O3 reduced at 800 °C showed similar ID/IG ratios (1.18, 1.21, and 1.22, respectively), and it was also consistent with TPO results (i.e., similar TPO profiles and lower peak temperature at ≈450 °C). The ID/IG ratios could not be determined for Ni/Al2O3 aerogel reduced at 800 °C and Ni-Al2O3 spinel reduced at 650 °C most likely because there was not enough carbon deposited on the surfaces, as suggested by the TPO profile. Ni-Al2O3 spinel reduced at 800 °C exhibited an ID/IG ratio similar to that of Ni/Al2O3 aerogel reduced at 650 °C (1.13 and 1.14, respectively); however, the TPO profiles were different. Overall, these results highlighted that the morphology of the produced carbon might be different even if they had similar crystallinity. 3.3.2 Morphology of carbon co-products HRTEM analysis reveals that the morphology of the produced carbon ranged from CNTs for the active catalyst to graphitic carbon layers for the lest active catalysts, suggesting that the catalytic activity is directly correlated to the co-product carbon. For example, Ni/Al2O3 aerogel reduced at 650 °C exhibited the highest activity, longest lifetime, and highest TPO peak temperature, and as demonstrated by HRTEM analysis, it favored the formation of CNTs. Figs. 7 shows that CNT formation was preferentially observed on larger Ni nanoparticles (>20 nm), and no selective tip- vs. base-growth CNT formation was observed on any of the regions evaluated. Areas containing small Ni nanoparticles do not appear to be active for CNT formation, but elemental maps show that carbon was deposited on them, Figure A.2c). The Ni/Al2O3 aerogel reduced at 800 °C in (Fig. 7 b), which had negligible TCD activity, showed no apparent selectivity toward the formation of CNT and was preliminary composed of small Ni nanoparticles (<10 nm). Ni-Al2O3 spinel reduced at 650 °C showed no catalytic activity. The spent catalyst was composed of small Ni nanoparticles (<10 nm), and no evidence of CNT formation was found, Fig. 8 a and Figure A.3. However, when Ni-Al2O3 spinel was reduced at 800 °C (Fig. 8 b and Figure A.4), larger (>10 nm) Ni nanoparticles and CNTs were observed. Interestingly, graphitic carbon layers were also formed surrounding small Ni nanoparticles (<10 nm), in Figure A5. Similar observations were found on Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4 regardless of reduction temperature, Figs. 9 and 10 . These results suggest that the TCD activity and CNT selectivity is mostly a structure sensitivity effect and independent of the support composition. That is, small Ni nanoparticles deactivate quickly because they favor the formation of graphitic carbon layers and large Ni nanoparticles remain stable for longer possibly because they favor the formation of CNTs. As shown in Figs. 7a and A. 5 a, Ni particles were contained inside the CNT suggesting that original Ni particles might be fragmenting during the CNT growth, which is consistent with previous work describing CNT growth mechanism [13,26,46–48]. TEM and XRD Ni particle size analysis of the spent catalysts (Table S2) support this observation and showed that the average Ni particle size became smaller during reaction. Therefore, we hypothesize that the deactivation observed (Fig. 3) is due to the decrease in Ni particle size during methane TCD. That is, as the Ni nanoparticle becomes smaller, its activity toward methane TCD (i.e., TOF) decreases and results in a gradual catalytic deactivation. As Ni nanoparticles reach a critical size (<10 nm), they become selective toward the formation of graphite layers (Fig. 5b) as opposed to CNT, which ultimately causes complete deactivation of the Ni nanoparticle. This hypothesis is further confirmed by elemental maps of the spent catalyst (Figures A.2-A.4) that show, regardless of the support composition, the catalyst areas with small Ni nanoparticles are consistently covered with carbon and do not show CNT formation. However, we note that the deactivation rate likely reflects a subtle balance because the diffusion of carbon through small particles is faster than carbon transport through larger particles. While diffusivity under reaction conditions as a function of the size of the metal particles has not been measured directly, it can be estimated in two steps: first by recalling the high degree of correlation (Fig. 11 ) between diffusivity and solubility of carbon [49] and then by recalling the correlation (Fig. 12 ) between carbon solubility and size of metal particles [50]. A combination of the two graphs (admittedly a pastiche of the behavior of different metals shows a monotonic trend showing the diffusivity of C decreases with increasing particle size of the metal (Fig. 13 ). The correlation is at least plausible for the group VIII metals that prefer fcc lattices. The slower migration of the carbon through the metal is consistent with a slower rate of growth of filaments from larger particles as noted by others [51]. However even though the carbon supplied by methane decomposition on larger particles is not rejected as rapidly in the form of filaments, in this study and in that of others [52] it is observed that the larger particles deactivate more slowly. We can offer a speculative rationalization of the faster deactivation of small particles with their faster diffusion of carbon and their faster formation of filaments. From the classic studies by van Hardeveld and Hartog of the statistics of surface sites [53], it is known that surfaces of small particles contain many fewer hexagonally symmetric basal sites ( C 9 3 ) sites in the nomenclature of van Hardeveld and Hartog) than do the surfaces of larger particles. If those sites were important to the formation of filaments then their relative sparsity could make the smaller particles more susceptible to poisoning or site blockage. 4 Conclusions Ni-based catalysts supported on Al2O3 or MgA2O4 were synthesized and investigated for TCD of methane at 650 °C. To vary catalyst properties and study their effects on TCD activity, the study catalysts were synthesized using different supports and reduction conditions. We found that the main parameters controlling the TCD performance was Ni(0) particle size. The catalysts became more selective toward CNT formation and had higher initial CH4 TOF as Ni(0) particle size increased to >20 nm. Smaller Ni(0) particles preferred the formation of graphitic carbon that facilitated a quicker rate of deactivation. The characterization of the carbon co-product showed that all carbon generated via TCD was crystalline. However large Ni(0) particles (>20 nm) favored CNT formation while small Ni(0) particles favored graphitic sheet formation. Taken together, results indicate that the Ni(0) particle size is the main parameter controlling both TCD activity and resulting morphology of the solid carbon co-product, as opposed to the properties of the support. The observed catalyst deactivation with time-on-stream is caused by the fragmentation of Ni(0) particles. When the Ni nanoparticles reach a particle size <10 nm, deactivation occurred by encapsulation within graphitic carbon layers. We hypothesize that the nature of the support affects the resulting Ni structure but does not likely contribute to TCD performance directly. coredata.dc:description: Thermocatalytic decomposition of methane (TCD) is a promising approach for producing CO2-free hydrogen and solid carbon co-product. In this study, a series of Al2O3- and MgAl2O4-based Ni catalysts, prepared with varying synthesis and pretreatment methods, were evaluated for methane TCD performance at 650 °C and characterized before and after reaction to elucidate activity-structure relationships. We found that methane TCD turnover increases with Ni particle size. Further, large Ni particle sizes (i.e., >20 nm) are selective toward the formation of carbon nanotubes (CNTs), while small Ni particle sizes (i.e., <10 nm) are selective toward the formation of graphitic carbon layers. The formation of graphitic carbon layers block access to Ni active sites, thus rendering the catalyst inactive more quickly than when CNTs are produced. Additionally, the catalyst deactivation observed with time-on-stream is due to the fragmentation of Ni particles into smaller Ni particles followed by their encapsulation with graphitic carbon layers.
coredata.dc:title: Structure sensitivity and its effect on methane turnover and carbon co-product selectivity in thermocatalytic decomposition of methane over supported Ni catalysts
